reviews.review_msg: If you don't have a sense of humour, I feel sorry for you.  But more importantly, don't take his class.  One of the best psych profs at SFU, totally made every class worth attending.  Funny as hell and VERY personable.    If I could give him a hot chili, I totally would.  :D
He is a fantastic and insightful Prof. who will go to the wall to help you understand the topic as long as you go in to see him.

Cannot rate this man high enough. This class is what the university experience should be about: he teaches you how to think and critically evaluate NOT regurgitate facts.  If you have issues with this then do yourself a favour and drop out of university or at least reconsider a career involving research. This school better give him a permanent job.

Tyler's teaching style is amazing! He's very passionate and this comes across in Lectures! At the start of the semester I found him a bit intimidating (due to the yelling a bit), I was hesitant to ask questions but when worked up the courage and went to talk to him in person he was incredibly nice and helpful!

Be warned: this class is more about what he hates about developmental psychologists rather than actual children's development. But Tyler is great, intelligent, hilarious and his lectures are really interesting. The assignments and exams are fair and his class provides a refreshing perspective on psychology. One thing: he yells when he's excited

Really great professor! Very fun class. Tyler has a gift with teaching and communicating important information to his students. Thought provoking class. learned more about how infants/children are studied than how they actually learn, so it was more theoretical than practical which was what I was expecting. Interesting perspective to learn from.

He is one of those rare charismatic profs. Didn't care for the way he tried to "revolutionize" exams, which were 7 essay questions that he said would be taken directly from the study questions but he ended up changing the questions on the exam. Buut it was easy nonetheless, I mean, it's psych, so nothing is going to be overly difficult.

He really forces you to consider what you're learning, and to think critically about how we study how children develop. Explicitly states he doesn't want you to just regurgitate what he's teaching. Assignments are pretty straight-forward; tests are somewhat difficult, but over all fair. Awesome professor, and very passionate about what he teaches.

This is literally the best prof I have EVER had in post secondary.  However, with that said, he also has some of the hardest tests I've ever had.  I would have failed with any other prof though.  However, Tyler's teaching skills are the best, so I managed to get through it.
Tyler is absolutely amazing!! It is not an easy course but Tyler's lecture is so much fun!! He is so easy to talk with and he knows what he is talking about. Highly recommend!!
Tyler is the most awesome pro I have ever met. Passionate! Crazy! Funny! Critical! Thought provoking! I like him madly!  And his never changed short wearing for the whole summer. Hhahahaha

Tyler is awesome. You can tell he loves what he teaches and is open to his students. However psyc 354 "development of children" should actually be called "how children are researched" it reminds me of a research methods class. I haven't learned anything about how children actually develop! Tyler's great but he should rename the course.

Tyler is by far the best TA I've ever had! He's down to earth and gives it to you straight- which is extremely refreshing. Not only is he an excellent teacher but a very approachable one. I wouldn't have achieved the same mark if I hadn't attended his tutorials! Definitely taking another class with him!

It's not often that you get a TA who is both knowledgeable and a good teacher, but Tyler is both. His tutorials are engaging, fun, and really helped me to understand the theories presented in lecture and the readings. I definitely recommend taking a course/tutorial with him if you get the chance.

really great prof. i also had a really helpful TA, so that helped. he's really into making sure that you learn the main concepts and nothing extra.  i preferred the take home exams to the standard midterm/final.
you know what.. if you really worry about ur GPA, dont take this course. This class is crazy. He really wants us to answer like graduate students. too hard to get even average.

You could do well on the test only if you had talked to him about the test questions. The questions HAVE to be written in a specific manner and specific information... If you couldn't see him or the TA at the alotted time, have fun.

Don't take a class with this guy! He talks in circles does not have a full grip on the content of the course. If you ask him a question it takes him 20 mins to answer! This guy has know idea what he is talking about! More like a philosophy class than a psych class.

He's a really nice and funny person to talk to and a good professor, just a little dry. I discovered that he's a southern american, and that explained the lengthy way he completes a sentence. Aside from that, he's very willing to talk to students in and out of class, and he's very helpful and kind, though he seems intimidating.

I found his style of lecturing a bit dry. He's very fair in that he tells you what will be on the exam. Pay VERY close attention to the lecture notes, because even something you think is a minute detail can be tested. He grows on you, but it takes him about 4 minutes to complete a sentence.

Great class if you don't mind a bit of philosophy and some different points of view than we are used to in psyc. Bryan tried to put a scare in us on the firtst day by warning us how challenging the course would be. Pay colse attention to the study questions, review and discussion portions of lectures and attend your tutorials and you will do fine.

Its too bad such a nice guy has to teach such a boring class. I can honestly say that although this professor grows on you, this class is a complete boring waste of time. Don't bother with the readings, they arnt on exam, just take awesome lecture notes, go to tutorial and memorize answers to questions.

I thought this was the easiest upperlevel psyc class @ sfu. Yes the readings are challenging but u don't need to understand/memorize it bcoz he only examines stuffs he said in class. The strategy to do well in this class is to PAY ATTENTION to his lecture notes & do the study questions! Do that=high marks. Tutorials are very helpful as well.

Awesome class! Great to learn the more philosophicla questions in psych.  Such an intellegent prof, a class that challenges you as a learner and leaves you with a feeling of higher education.  Totally take this class!

TOUGH COURSE! Expects us to read and understand research papers targeted towards grad students and professors. Tutorials are essential and study questions ESSENTIAL. Very interesting ideas though and interested theories, just a bit too hard for a 3rd year course because of the readings.

nice person, approachable..no surprises on tests, very fair. course a content a bit philosphical and abstract, doesnt really apply to real life but not too bad. not much studying and readings are not exam

Very nice prof, though he does tend to speak slow :) The 1st 1/2 of the course is a bit philosophical, but it picks up.  He gives you the essay ?'s before the exam-make sure you define EVERYTHING on your exam ?'s to get full the marks!! U R graded on the content of essay (specific terms/phrases). :)

I have grown quite fond of this prof.  He is absolutely amazing. He talks a bit slow at times, and may put you to sleep.  BUt if you do the work, you'll definately get the mark in this.  He is passionate about the course, he is overall awesome.

Quite interesting if ur into philosophical stuff. Tests arent too bad, he gives you the q's way ahead of time and you just have to memorize the answers-- BUT! he does expect alot so dont get me wrong!... He's really nice and tutorials help soooo much! All in all, good class and prof.

Pretty demanding of what he wants; his tests are pretty restrictive,which is weird considering he is very phiosophical. Tutorials totally help keep you on track though and know what he wants. Overall, the class isn't too bad, just a lot of reading. Listen closely to his lectures and you'll do fine.

He is an awesome, challanging professor. He forces you to think in ways you would have never done before. He gives a very heavy reading load, though, so if that is a problem i would say think again. But overall i think he is great.
too much philosophical stuff!!! No one understands what he is talking about!
Boring class ever!!!

awesome prof..lectures were funny great and entertaining....tests: multiple choice based on textbook material and short answer questions based on lecture material...use the study guide and you will be fine...great class

I enjoyed taking Jeremy's class and having a TA like Beau really made the class more enjoyable. While I do agree that his lectures can be quite dry, the course material is honestly interesting. He's accessible and he really cares about his students. The class was based on 2 exams, a paper and participation - go to tutorial as Beau makes it fun!

Jeremy is quiet and simple. It's hard to stay engaged in lecture. He cares about his students, though, and accommodated distancing by making the exams online. He also provided a study guide! The TA, Beau, was the real winner, which accommodated Jeremy's lack of engagement. He helped turn the course around and helped us understand concepts!

This class was only marked on 2 exams and a paper, with 10% on going to tutorials. Jeremy is poor in lectures, goes through material super fast and does not explain well at all. Tons of people I know in this class hated it because how poor the lectures were and left not learning anything new. Basically we taught yourselves everything, good luck
I appreciate the study questions that he gives out before exams, but i think his teaching style and lecture materials could be clearer, more engaging and more organised.

Jeremy really cares for others and has a kind soul. His course was the least stressful for me, and his tests are completely from the questions he gives previously. If you study those, you'll get an A. If you get a TA like Beau as well, you'll get an A.

Jeremy is nice, I think he is very knowledgeable and insightful. I like the course, I didn't think it was that difficult. However, it does have a lot of theories and it require a bit of thinking and reasoning, so that's where it gets a bit confusing. But over all it's great, not a lot of work loads. Definitely recommend it :)

Dr. Carpendale is just SOOOOO AMAZING!!!!! It is a must take class and if I could, I would take it ALL over again!! He is very caring towards his students, really wants you to learn the materials, very passionate about what he teaches, and his lectures/materials he was teaching was WAYY beyond just valuable !!!! HIGHLY recommended!!!

Jeremy is a warm and caring prof who wants to see students learn. He talks to students like they are equals. He provides prep questions to allow you to prepare for exams. Do them and you will do well! He is also very approachable and will try to explain any concepts you don't understand.

Jeremy is an excellent teacher!!! Great course. He lays out the themes of the course from he beginning and does a great job of relating all material to them. He gives study questions to prepare students for the exams. His powerpoints are not useless-  listen to what he says in lecture to add on to the lecture slides and everything will make sense!

The information he presents is interesting but his ability to bring it to the level of understanding that an undergraduate student is likely to have on the material leaves something to be desired. Make use of the TA's and tutorials and you will likely do well.

Classes weren't the most interesting. Make sure to do all the study questions and memorize them well, as he will pick questions from the list. Do well on the midterm - the midterm is easier than the final. Overall an easy class if you're good with memorizing and writing essays.

Jeremy really tries his best to explain difficult theories and concepts in this course. If you print out the lecture slides and add extraneous notes presented in lecture, you can do well in this class. I suggest asking your TA in tutorials for clarification in concepts, you may not have understood in class. Put in the effort and you will do well.

When I read the other comments on Jeremy prior to taking his class, I was scared. But he is a genuinely nice guy, and his class is thoroughly pass-able if you are willing to put in the effort to understand GENERAL principles. Short-answer exams, no text (just articles)- grade does depend on your TA.

He is a terrible teacher. He seems like a nice guy but he is not helpful at all. I e-mailed him repeatedly and he usually replied with just one word answers. His exams are too tough (consist of 6 -7 question? wtf?), and his material is completely irrelevant to what we SHOULD be learning. Terrible teacher, terrible class. Do not take him.

Does not convey material well in lecture (disconnected), TA and tut. were useless in helping. 20+ Hours spent studying, 13 pages of answers to 30 review questions, 5 hours listening to lecture recordings, another few committed to reviewing lecture notes. Still manage to fail the final exam. Final mark: C-. This is coming from a 3.4GPA student.
really nice guy but yes his lectures can be boring. however, his course seems harder than it actually is. At the end, i think people are generally pleasantly surprised by their grade.

He is not clear with explanations, and jumps all over the place. The course involves too many thoeries; is too philosophical. The marking is pretty fair though. I never did readings and I still got a B.
A lot of complicated theories will little comprehensible explanations.
The class overall was okay. My TA was amazing and therefore had a huge impact. The prof's teaching ability was mediocre at best. His notes were hard to follow and his lectures were unclear.

I found this class very hard. Prof was too philosophical, course is misleading to think it discusses children's thinking. Based more on other topics rather than children. Unclear, unfair marking, poor preparation for exams. Avoid this prof and take Sokol

It's easy to diss this class and say it sucks, but you can't deny that he really tries very hard to be as helpful as possible. He's very shy, lecture notes not very clear, class is boring, covers a few topics but very in-depth. Hardest PSYC class I took. Tutorials are useful ONLY if your TA is.
not very clear.  marks very hard

definitely not an easy course. heavy reading. he's a really nice guy and explains the readings well. class can be boring. i wouldn't recommend this course to someone that wasn't REALLY interested in children's thinking. on the other hand, i did learn a lot of interesting things.
lectures are a bit disorganized but jermey does a good job of explaining the material in the courseware.  tutorials are VERY helpful for this course.

Excellent prof.  Does a good job of explaining complex issues.  Lazy students don't want to study and complain when they don't understand.  Material is challenging.  Excellent depth, well designed course.  Among favorite courses ever.
this course sucked! i DO NOT recommend it to anyone unless they are SERIOUSLY interesting in that crap
absolute worse prof I have ever had.  Does not know how to convey material in a effective way to students.
very dull and boring with dense material that is completely unrelated to anything useful, uses big words yet says nothing, warning, do not take this class!
